comments.commentBody: Finding Dermatologists that specialize in hair loss. Good luck. Many want nothing to do with hair loss patients preferring to push the Botox instead.  Please address the current recommended treatment of female alopecia androgenica.  Is there a role for systemic anti-androgen medication?
RON LIEBER: I apologize. “Incentivize” is a legitimate but very highly unusual and uncommon verb. I could not resist the jibe as too many people have erroneously made verbs out of nouns.

Actually, those who describe "big brother" concerns have a point.

But I think the right thing is to untangle health insurance away from employers so it is both your own business what your blood pressure is, but it is also your bigger bill.

Or if we go the socialized route (I'm not totally against it) then it should still be a bigger bill for those costing the system more.

For those of you who are having trouble with the google maps, search the address and let your location appear. Once google maps has found your location, clear the address bar, leaving the map on the page, and type in 'real estate' (no apostrophes). That should do the trick.

Buying foreclosures is not a morally neutral process. In some cases, you will find people who bit off more than they could chew and are losing a home they didn't have much business being in. Most foreclosures today, however, are the result of a grimy process of rich, morally bankrupt folks who took our nation's middle class for a ride. Throw in all our existing racial, ethnic, and class inequities, and one is likely to face a formidable psychological transaction that is anything but neutral. It might not hurt to look up loan history, which is available, to see what you're getting into and if you're comfortable buying a particular foreclosure. There are cases where one is not preying on another's misfortune, just hard to tease out which those are in our current economy.
TCU should be the number one team in the country!

@Michael Lewis (Michael Lewis, really? Please) - Mets fans are loyal because they support a team that doesn't win all the time. They care deeply how well the team does. For true fans, sports allegiance isn't soap - I'm not going to switch being a Yankee fan because they are winning.

What I'd like to see, though, is ticket prices that drop as the game approaches, like hotel rooms.
Placing the blame on Pederson stems from vindictive Nebraska fans who want to see Pederson's career ruined despite the fact that their latest coaching hire has been no less controversial.

Sound's like the University is left with serious problems....It seems to me like racial undertone. Why wouldn't you allow the coach to at least explain/exhonerate himself... It's the American way; isn't football America's sport?!
It may be worth rethinking the premise of this question. This summary of psychological research shows that all incentives tend to backfire: http://bit.ly/yngDx

A memory, a sudden insight, is my incentive. The light went on when I realized that AFTER exercising (dance class, walking, bicycling), I never once regretted doing it. It was only BEFORE exercising that I said to myself, "I'm too tired," "I don't have time," "I need to do ______ now instead."  I saw that the hardest part was putting on the walking shoes and getting out the door. So I just remind myself that I've never regretted exercising once I've done it. The reluctance to start is an illusion. Second incentive --I always feel better after exercising. That's another useful memory! Just walk if you have no plan . . . it's good for thinking, too.

To those who feel there's something morally wrong with buying foreclosures: It is extremely sad when someone loses a home but those who buy the home as a foreclosure are not causing further harm to the previous owners.  They are helping the economy. This economy is not going to get better until most of the foreclosures are sold.

@ all the people whining about those looking for a foreclosure to live in.

I said LIVE in. Not buy to rent like John Gardner above who will realize soon that his$850 a month tenants will only be able to afford $350,

Many foreclosures DIDN'T have people living in them. Many people bought 2nd 3rd and 4th houses with visions of sugarplums and $$$$$$'s dancing in their heads and used kinky toxic financing in order to do so.

Those people contributed greatly to driving up the cost of homes pricing the rest of us out. They not only deserve to lose their "houses" but deserve more than that. Jail perhaps?

The people who bought too much home and were foreclosed out of the place where they lived will realize that their house was never worth that much and if the banks quit playing ther $%^%$ games, these people too will be able to afford a house without using a toxic ARM loan.

For the people who actually ARE losing their houses due to loss of job, I can say this. Renters are ALSO losing jobs. These people don't need the government to give them a free house (although they all seem to want it even though renters aren't given a free apartment) they need the government to create JOBS.

I bought my first and only home eight years ago here in the Midwest. I bought it without an agent and FSBO. The process hasn't been without hills and valleys but no major problems to speak of. The best advice is common sense: Buy something solid (hold out for charming) at a good price in a good neighborhood. My house was listed thousands of dollars below fair market value. I knew the price was fair--and also that I could have bargained the seller down by a few more thou. I chose not to. That made the homebuying experience very pleasant for me.

Get your inspections, make sure the roof is in excellent shape, have the heat and air closely scrutinized. If you purchase the house at a good price, this will leave you thousands of dollars to put in your home repair nest egg.

Canvas your network of friends and have a good plumber and handyman/carpenter available, should you need them. One individual with a small crew who has an outstanding reputation will likely be innovative and creative with home repairs.

My windows are painted shut, by the way (re. an earlier comment). You can't expect everything to be perfect, especially if you are buying an older house and getting a good price.

Good luck!

RIght up my alley Ron!

I incentivized myself to quit smoking back in March. I got fed up with giving the tobacco companies my $'s and it was the best way to say "%#$$% you" to overpriced healthcare. The only thing is that the thing that I "incentivized" myself with was a Marilyn Manson watercolor print (When I Get Old). Now I don't really want it as it's just "stuff". Time to go work out in the basement gym!

P.S.

Houses are still too expensive. ;^)
I once was a celery stick, than a sweet potato, but now I'm turning into a squash.

As a person of a far more certain age of 69, the words "call collect" are clear and obvious. If you expect someone else to pay for a phone call, you must call the operator who, in turn, calls the number and verifies that someone there will agree to the charges. It's "obvious."

But clearly, it wasn't obvious to you. And only after reading of your experience did I realize just how long it's been since I actually did make a collect call. VERY LONG.

There's a good reason too. Even though I live in Taiwan now, I am a native-born American and I retain all of my citizenship and a number of accounts in the US. I use Skype for my international calling and here is the GREAT NEWS: "no matter what it says on the back of your credit card, you can call US based toll-free numbers from ANYWHERE using Skype and the call is free to you. So you don't have to bother with the complex and tedious procedure from 'prehistoric times' known as calling collect. Just use Skype.

Of course, in your situation, you lost your laptop, so using Skype would have been a bit complex, but probably still possible from an Internet Cafe. But the details are a bit complex for this comment.

The idea of an annual health risk analysis together with healthy behavior credits is part of the picture. It's also essential to include pharmacy coaching and networked oversight across all docs addressing a given patient, and to shift back-end critical care spending toward less expensive front-end prevention and wellness care. This needs to occur in context with transparent cost and outcome data visible to patients and disintermediated payors. Also needed is a coherent medical health record accessible by practitioners and patients to track health patterns by patient and and population to identify what is going on with a person over time and to see what works to alert practitioners to lessons learned under given conditions, especially for multiple morbidity scenarios.

To get health care we want to pay for, you need to show there's a positive Return on Investment and marketable regional competitiveness from significantly lower labor and social overhead. The strategy is to apply existing money to cut outlays by improving results. Step-wise state-wide implementation includes insureds, underinsureds, and uninsureds. It aims directly at loss control payment policy and high-consequence risk mitigation. It redeploys current back-end spending to invest in front-end loss mitigation and patient incentives for chronic-persistent care, high-consequence risk mitigation for workplace accidents, accessible patient-centric regional medical village teams for population prevention and wellness, and action focused transparent health information technology.

Individuals, self-insured employers, and public managers all benefit from loss control strategies and high-consequence risk mitigation strategies applied to chronic and persistent conditions, wellness care, and activity scenarios. The 20% of the population with chronic and persistent conditions drives over 75% of all health care cost, yet today only some 3% of health spending aims at preventive care. Dealing with chronic and persistent conditions and wellness care, and managing acute care incidence with a high-consequence risk mitigation strategy for workplace activity, opens the door to significant and sustainable savings from better outcomes for the whole regional population. The inclusive and accountable region-wide gain-share results drive better health, lower cost, higher productivity, and stronger regional and global economic advantage leading to more and better jobs and better wages.

Ron - thank for your helpful article. Rising healthcare costs are one of the largest reasons why unemployment is stuck near 10%. Most people don't realize that benefits represent 30-40% of employee costs (the other 60-70% is salary/wages). With employer healthcare costs rising at +10% annually, it's no wonder that employers are holding back from adding full time employees to their payroll. Further the increasing healthcare entitlement liability for our country is a threat to our economy and standard of living. It's popular to blame doctors, insurance companies and employers for the healthcare crisis, as it deflects personal responsibility.  The truth is we, as Americans, are poor consumers of healthcare.  As a result we use the healthcare system too often, for the wrong reasons, with the majority of resources spent to fix problems that could be prevented. It's unfortunate that we need to incentivize (sorry language police) ourselves to take care of themselves, however that's the reality we face. Just as seatbelt, helmet, and speed limit laws have saved many lives, healthcare incentives could be one step toward saving our healthcare system and economy.  Plus it would have the added benefit of people feeling better and being more productive.  There is a separate article in today's NY Times about the first Baby Boomers turning 65 today. This is a great reminder of the need for real improvements to healthcare, not blame and taxation.  I appreciate this article for highlighting some creative and constructive ways to address the challenge.

I completely sympathize with your experience. I don't think that banks are doing enough to help their customers when traveling abroad.

I had similar problems with Bank of America when they cancelled by card due to what they deemed "suspicious activity" - that is, the fact that the card was being used on non-U.S. territory. I tried calling collect from a pay phone - via an operator - and it didn't work. The operator told me that the number wasn't being recognized. This was in France, and then later in Italy. I ended up going to an internet cafe and calling the bank on Skype from a pre-paid U.S. Skype number. The frustrating process of repeatedly being put on hold and given contradictory information and instructions usually lasted up to one hour, but I only paid at most 2 euros (for the internet connection). The bank said they would reimburse me for the costs but by then I was sick of engaging with bank representatives (I had to explain my situations about a dozen times in one phone call) so I decided against initiating the procedure to get any money back. It wasn't too much anyway.

The point is that banks should do more to help you out when traveling abroad. Just because the collect numbers are "supposed" to work when processed via operators doesn't mean they do. They often don't. There are many reasons for this, but the bottom line is that banks should be aware of this and try to fix the problem. It wouldn't be that terrible if they didn't have you on hold for half an hour and then offer up what often feels like incompetent customer service (or incompetently trained).

I hope they shape up, and perhaps more blog postings and articles like these will help get that done. Thanks.

Be wary of short sales. My husband and I were in contract for five months for a short sale.  The deal fell apart a few weeks ago, partially because the seller's bank appeared to be more interested in punishing the sellers than in closing the contract and moving the house off the market.  After three to four years of defaults, banks still remain ill equipped to handle the mess. If banks sold their housing inventory, the housing market would recover at a faster rate.  We will NEVER consider a short sale again.

Discipline, whether it is about making choices in favor of one's health or any other activity, is having the ability to choose those actions that favor long term objectives instead of immediate gratifications or desires. Neither fear of ill health nor money (health insurance discounts)  are sufficient incentives to overcome impulse behavior or to provide good long term incentives for a person to engage in  lifelong habits to support and promote good health; at best they may provide a window of opportunity for education on good health habits and measures. The person has to actually want to be healthy, to know what that means, and to be able to and to consistently make choices in favor of his or her health, whether it means choosing a salad over a cheeseburger, walking instead of riding or paying for the dentist visit even if one doesn't have dental insurance. I recommend Robert Fritz's book "The Path of Least Resistance" for a clear description and analysis of this process.

Hi Ron, I just sent you an email. We've created a company that rewards people for exercising. Anyone can join so long as they use a fitness app such as Nike+, Garmin, Fitbit, etc. We can be found at www.earndit.com.

There are many other new companies that are turning healthy living into a game: www.healthmonth.com, www.dailyfeats.com, www.socialworkout.com.

Happy new year!

An REO sale is much simpler than a short sale, so Andrew's comment #22 don't necessarily reflect reality. An REO has a bank for a seller and once they put the foreclosed property on the market the banks really do want to sell them. A short sale still has a human seller in the middle of the process and many banks aren't reconciled to taking a significant loss on their loan. A typical short sale still takes months to complete, and many short sale deals fall apart for a variety of reasons. Please don't consider REO and short sales as similar transactions.
Many realtors with web sites have a section for viewing foreclosure listings.  You can often sign up to be notified of new listings as they arise.

I'm with #3 and 4, although the use of "incentivize" does clearly and immediately signal the overall corporate drone perspective of this column.  I'm also with #17 -- anyone who thinks this is some sort of benevolent tactic to help employees maintain good health is pretty foolish.
